column2: Gluttony is another one of the 7 deadly sins.
It signifies over indulgence
column3: lack of self righteousness and is often symbolized by a pig.

column2: In the past gluttony played a role in my life.
It’s not that I always over eat... it’s that I’ve had past addictions that separated me from reality.
I over indulged to numb life and slip away from reality.
It took its toll on me as I didn’t give attention to the areas in my life that needed it most.
My past experience with gluttony is that during my pursuit to numb my mind I was withholding my attention to the areas of my life that needed it most.
These days gluttony and over indulgence doesn’t really play a part in my life.
I don’t drink nor do drugs.
I really over eat.
Most meals I can’t finish and end up sharing my left overs with Bobo or The Man.
If necessary I can go a couple of days without eating if that means ensuring every one else does get to eat (this situation isn’t applicable now
column3: but it was during the darker days).

column2: So my analysis from self examination is that gluttony is not one of the seven deadly sins that I am guilty of.
I’ll be ranking them as I write.
So here’s the list (1 being the sin I am most guilty of
column3: 7 the least).

column2: Vanity
Gluttony
For next blog
column3: I’ll discuss Sloth

column2: Before I dive into the nitty gritty of this blog
column3: I have a few things I want to say so you are very clear on how I feel.

column2: The most important thing to note is that this entry is a rant
column3: my opinion on RELIGION.

column2: I will not try to talk you out of your beliefs nor will I debate mine.
Spirituality is a personal journey and whatever your beliefs might be
column3: I respect that.

column2: By no means ever will I cast judgement on a person based on what God they follow.
I am a human
column3: like you.

column2: It is not my place.
I guess that sums that up.
Onwards...
I was brought up in a strict Roman Catholic household.
We were in the pews every Sunday Mass.
We abstained from eating meat for lent.
I was baptized in the church.
I gave the readings at my first communion.
I went to confession and if I had nothing to confess
column3: well I made stuff up.

column2: I prayed to the Lord Almighty
column3: Heavenly Father

column2: After I was confirmed
column3: I never went to church again.

column2: I never found comfort in my religion.
I had so many questions that were never wanted
column3: approved of

column2: As a young adult I began to research as many religions as I could.
In the end
column3: I’ve found my answers

column2: Without taking you by the ankles and dragging you down the rabbit hole with me
column3: I’ll say this: I’m pagan.

column2: I believe in many gods and goddesses.
I do not “worship” them.
Instead my devotion is to the Earth.
I believe in ghosts
column3: spirits

column2: I do not believe in a heaven nor hell.
I do believe that I have a moral obligation however and conduct myself appropriately.
I strongly do not believe that the bible is the word of god.
I do not believe a group of men have the right to cherry pick how I should live my life.
I hope I didn’t offend any of my readers.
If it works for you fantastic.
I however have many issues with Christianity and the bible.
I do not have issues with people who follow this faith however.
I respect you as a person and the beliefs you hold dear.
Me
column3: categorizing myself as Pagan DOES not mean I pray to a false god or the devil.

column2: I can not make my children learn a religion that I do not whole heartedly believe in.
For this reason they are  not baptised.
If they show an interest in a particular religion I encourage them to exam it.
I will never be the one to hold back faith.
Now having said all that (and feel free to ask any questions)... here is the rant.
Today it happened.
Deedee (who is Wiccan) came home from school and said that her teacher called Wiccan’s devil worshippers.
I was floored.
I was so tempted to call the school and give them the wrath of an angry mama lion.
Before I could give in to my anger
column3: I knew I needed to calm down and objectify the situation.

column2: I live in the bible belt.
How I choose to proceed with this could affect all 3 of my children for the rest of their public school career.
After asking a few co workers if any of the town’s high school teachers preached Christianity in the classroom
column3: I learned that some do.

column2: I can not blame someone for their commitment of their faith
column3: but it angers me when they harshly judge something they hardly know anything about and misrepresent the facts – and to children no less.

column2: My options here are limited.
If I make a big to do about this
column3: I could be perceived as attacking a teacher who other than this is a really great teacher.

column2: I won’t be in the middle of this feud.
My kids will be and they don’t want that.
They know fact from opinion.
I can use these incidents as lessons in tolerance instead.
I could pull them out of school or switch schools
column3: but that won’t end things.

column2: I need to make the best out of these difficult moments and demanding that religion be left out of school just isn’t going to fly here.
I’m in a rock and a hard place.
I’ve talked in depth with Deedee about it and she doesn’t want me to make a big to do out of it.
I know Deedee doesn’t worship the devil and Deedee knows it.
That should be what really matters.
The irony is that said teacher doesn’t know Deedee is Wiccan and constantly praises Deedee for being such a good student (who doesn’t get in trouble
column3: who always completes assignments
column5: and doesn’t talk out of turn).

column2: This is one of those times I need to let it be
column3: but for Deedee I’m wounded.

column2: Ever since I was a child the “7 deadly sins” held my interest.
What I thought was intriguing is that they were never listed among the 10 commandments.
Although when exploring each deadly sin in depth it is easy to see how engaging in this behavior can lead to an immoral character.
I will write about each sin and how they affect my life.
I am starting with pride / vanity as currently I can see parallels between this sin and my view of myself.
Pride / Vanity is said to be the most vile
column3: the most deadly sin out of the 7.

column2: A perfect example of this sin is a self absorbed narcissist who demands constant validation and acceptance from others.
They seek compliments  and put themselves above others.
This is a form of self idolatry.
I think I can be a vain person when it comes to how demanding I am with how I look.
I obsess over my hair.
It’s always perfect.
I insist upon it.
I love make up.
I have quite a few dresser drawers devoted to my lotions
column3: my lip sticks

column2: I don’t leave the house with out my tribal make up and my hair styled impeccably.
Certain nights of the week I sleep with a mixture of coconut oil and aragon oil massaged into my hair.
I wear a shower cap to protect my pillow cases.
15 minutes before I take a shower I lather honey all over my entire face and let it sit until I bath.
In my younger days (and I’m so sorry for my arrogance) I have actually had the nerve to say “If I ever get fat just shoot me” ... on multiple occasions.
How insensitive could I have been!
Karma has kicked in and now I have a pot belly.
So what do I do?
I’ve been fixated on dieting and exercising.
Could it be that I’m vain?
Humility is the opposite of vanity / pride.
I love to make other people feel good.
I love to give sincere
column3: gooey

column2: I place the value of myself above no one.
We as people are ALL equal.
I leave judgement up to higher powers.
I can be quite modest.
Although I am highly indulgent in a consuming grooming routine
column3: if you were to compliment me I would shyly say thank you and blush.

column2: I don’t like people gushing over me.
I give respect to those who have earned it and I give credit it where it is properly do.
So am vain?
Is there another sin I’m in deep with?
Next blog will be about gluttony.
When The Man was a child his older brother got hit by a truck and tragically died.
The catastrophic event has forever haunted his family since.
I’m sorry
column3: but I can’t go into private details that surround this unfortunate accident.

column2: I wasn’t there
column3: didn’t know the family back then
column4: and I certainly didn’t know the boy.

column2: While dating The Man our relationship grew ever more serious.
He met my family.
I met his.
He saw all my old family photos.
I saw his.
I told him all about the skeletons in my closet.
He dug up his old bones in turn for me.
So I learned in confidence all about *B* (The Man’s brother) and his untimely demise and how effected it left The Man ever after.
We had our first child
column3: Deedee.

column2: Life was great
column3: but it became very clear to us that Deedee is a highly gifted child.

column2: She grew too big too quick.
We knew we wanted a family with several kids so when Deedee was a month shy of 2
column3: BoBo came into this world right on cue.

column2: Bobo’s first moments outside of me were almost his last.
It was a complicated delivery and to this day
column3: Bobo still deals with obstacles created by those first crucial hours.

column2: Life with Bobo was chaotic
column3: hectic

column2: He screamed and wailed for hours upon hours.
I knew he hurt and yet I couldn’t soothe him.
I felt like I was failing my infant son.
As he grew we did what most parents do
column3: we documented his growth with picture after picture.

column2: It was great memere who brought it to my attention at first.
BoBo acts and looks just like his dead uncle.
When pictures of the boys were put next to each other even I could not always tell which child was my beloved son.
Soon all the grandparents and extended family members were commenting how astonished they were by the extreme similarities.
“Well they should look alike”
column3: I thought.

column2: “They are from  the same bloodline”.
Bobo frequently had nightmares and night terrors.
He’d scream in his sleep as if his limbs were being torn from his body.
He’d choke on his tears and shriek at the top of his tiny lungs.
It was horrendous watching him go through this.
When he was around 3 years old
column3: I was finally able to ask him about his nightmares.

column2: What he told me shocked me.
He told me he was riding a toy down the street (a scooter
column3: we were later able to identify it
column4: but at 3 Bobo didn’t know what a scooter was).

column2: He rode the toy down a hill when suddenly a big truck hit him and he died.
Again
column3: I shall not go into graphic details
column4: but Bobo accurately described how his uncle died... only thing was Bobo didn’t know anything about *B* and especially not his death.

column2: One day I was driving through a town near where we lived.
I drove by a cemetery.
Bobo informed me as the car past by the headstones “that’s where my body is”.
I found out years later that the cemetery I had passed was the one *B* was buried in.
One day when Bobo was a toddler and my third child had just been born
column3: we went to a picnic at a nature persevere.

column2: It was a huge friend and family type event.
I sat at a table feeding my newborn baby (Snoochie) next to *J* (The Man’s cousin).
A lady I didn’t know sat down next to me (hoping to get to see the little cherub cradled in my arms).
She looked out at a field where The Man was playing kick ball with Deedee
column3: Bobo

column2: I watched as her face grew white and she clutched *J*’s arm.
“J” She gasped.
“Look at that little boy.” She pointed right at Bobo.
“I’m seeing a ghost
column3: J. That’s little *B* + last name.

column2: He’s dead though.
Do you see him?
There’s a ghost out there with those kids!” She was clearly shocked and freaked out.
I didn’t know who she was though.
Turns out she was a neighbor from when The Man and *B* were children.
J turned calmly to the lady and said.
“That’s no ghost.
That’s Bobo + last name
column3: *B*’s nephew.

column2: Look over there” he exclaimed pointing at The Man.
“That’s his dad
column3: The Man”.

column2: The lady had no clue I was Bobo’s mom.
I watched her relax and finally understand that she wasn’t seeing a ghost at all
column3: just some very dominant DNA.

column2: Some times Bobo knows things he shouldn’t.
Things about *B*.
Things there is no possible way he could know.
I’ve got to wonder if *B* was sent back for another chance at life.
A lot of the family finds it unsettling how uncanny the resemblance is between the two boys
column3: but The Man doesn’t care.

column2: He loves his brother even through the barrier of death and he loves the son he has now.
Dear Pb
I miss you.
Remember all of the silly names I had for you
column3: my bunny bumpkins.

column2: I want you to know that I loved you dearly.
Memories of your buggy brown eyes will forever put a smile on my face.
I love the way you grunted and honked at the vacuum.
Your silly rabbit antics were endless.
I hated washing dishes
column3: but to look down and see you at my feet made those darn dishes bare able.

column2: Some people have teddy bears.
When I watched tv in bed I had you.
I’m sorry I couldn’t take you with me.
I wish with all my heart that I could brought you with us.
I feared such a huge move would have killed you.
Pb
column3: you are a cure for the blues.

column2: When I gave you to Crystal it’s because I knew she’d take good care of you.
What I didn’t foresee was that like I had once
column3: she needed you.

column2: I think of you from time to time.
I hope you still get chances to hop around outside and nibble yummy leaves.
I wish you were here
column3: but I’m so glad that you give some one else all your bunny reasons to smile.

column2: Can I tell you a little secret?
It’s one that’s nagged at me for most of my life
column3: eating a way slowly at my conscious

column2: Here it goes... I use to think I was evil.
Seriously.
I’m the girl with the bad vibe who your parents told you to stay clear of.
I most certainly don’t look evil.
I’m very petite with a thin
column3: angular face
column4: and cat like eyes that change color.

column2: I have long slender arms with delicate
column3: frail wrists.

column2: Physically
column3: I don’t look strong nor intimidating.

column2: I will admit I’m one of those people who have facial expressions that always seem to range upon annoyance.
Those who know me know you really can’t judge my thoughts by face.
They don’t act in accord.
I most certainly don’t act evil although I must admit
column3: I was a very rambunctious youth.

column2: I have a limitless amount of energy.
I’m always moving and sometimes I just can’t seem to shut up.
I have a huge heart.
I always want to offer up good
column3: sound advice or a positive solution.

column2: I love to learn about people
column3: make friends
column4: compliment every pleasing thing I see.

column2: I literally long to make other people happy and I expect nothing back in return.
That’s why in the past
column3: I’ve had such a hard time with people.

column2: Something about me draws them close.
Once I’m happy with this new found blossoming relationship something goes wrong.
My new buddy pulls away
column3: withdraws like I am a cursed leper and I’m left wondering “What did I do?” “What did I say?” It use to really hurt me deep
column4: but now I’ve learned to just let it be.

column2: Move on
column3: be myself

column2: I’ve never killed anyone.
Very few times do I think I was a bully.
I’m not violent.
I try not to lie
column3: nor gossip

column2: I don’t cheat.
I don’t steal.
I can pick apart my strengths and my weaknesses.
I never quite understood why people acted like I was a bad omen.
I may never know all the reasons for it.
The truth is I’ve learned a great lesson.
I have learned to rise above it and ignore it.
I can be no more than my true self.
Others are well within their personal rights to not like me even if it’s for no reason or one that makes no sense.
I won’t push back with the coldness they’ve given me.
I’ll keep a smile on my face and take stock of all that I am blessed with.
I won’t waste my energy holding grudges.
I’m not a resentful person.
I am light and like light
column3: I bounce.

column2: For many years I thought I was cursed
column3: born evil

column2: I tried not to let it hold me under because it was out of my realm of control.
Then one day I had an overwhelming epiphany.
Goodness is a choice.
Evil is a choice.
It’s not a condition that you are born with.
You are evil when you actively choose to be morally corrupt.
If I do not act in a vile manner how can I possibly be “simply” bad.
I can not.
I am not a victim of circumstance.
I have free will.
So you see
column3: I was wrong to let people’s misjudgements weigh so heavily on my soul.

column2: In the end their judgements can hold no candle to the love that is in my heart.
In fact
column3: I feel sorry for them.

column2: I give them my peace and love instead.
I’m actually planning on blogging about an idea for a specific topic today
column3: but before I dive into that subject matter I’d like to share an overview of my day so far.

column2: Yesterday Snoochie picked me some wild flowers that have already started to bloom in our back yard.
Delicate white flowers with little green dashes at the tips of the petals and purple star shaped flowers now sit on my bed side table.
The aroma is intoxicating and reminds me of a floral perfume.
I’m not the only one in the house enjoying the sweet bouquet.
Jake
column3: our kitten
column4: keeps leaning in to inhale the fragrance.

column2: This morning I awoke to the sound of hysterical screaming and crying.
Still half asleep
column3: my heart pounded in my chest and a lump immediately swelled in my throat.

column2: Did one of the cats die?
I quickly opened my bedroom door and realized the screaming was coming from my overly dramatic Snoochie.
She stole one of Bobo’s sneakers and was cruelly playing keep-a-way.
Aggravated
column3: Bobo shoved his little sister on to the floor and took back his shoe.

column2: The Man stepped in and separated them.
Really not a great way to wake up.
Today’s work out went fantastic!
I jogged at a steady pace for 20 minutes.
I read a few articles about how to effectively exercise and they mentioned using short
column3: intense bursts of energy into a steady paced workout.

column2: This is supposed to help speed up your metabolism.
So at every 5 minute interval I ran like a bat out of hell for 45 seconds.
After my jog
column3: I did some basic steps.

column2: My rhythm is improving.
At some point I’d like to make up a step routine of my own.
I did some strength training (alternating lunges and turbo twists).
Today I ended my routine with yoga instead of starting with it.
I must admit I am still a little sore
column3: but not nearly as bad as I felt yesterday.

column2: Once I started moving around
column3: my legs and aching thighs gave no indication of the strenuous torture I’ve been putting them through these past few days.

column2: I have a hunch that tomorrow these aches and pains will be even less of a nuisance to me than they were today.
I don’t have to work until 4pm tomorrow so I’ll be able to work out in the morning.
A few nights ago Deedee sat by my side while I was blogging.
She was very curious about all the different things I like to write about and read.
She confessed to having a blog of her own that remains entry-less because she never knows what to write about.
We discussed all the different choices for a topic she could use: her day
column3: her dreams
column6: you can literally pull a topic out of a hat I explained.

column2: So I too
column3: have decided to write my thoughts on a seemingly random topic.

column2: In fact I picked one topic so big that I can divide it into 7 different blogs.
The Seven Deadly Sins.
I think I’m going to tackle vanity first.
That’s what my next entry will be all about.
I haven’t written on update of daily life stuff in awhile because there hasn’t been too much going on.
The Man’s work schedule has changed and we’ve finally started adjusting to it.
He went from being a 3rd shift warrior to working 2nd shift.
Ugh.
It’s disappointing because now he isn’t home during the week day evenings and doesn’t get to see the kids very much.
He wakes up early to see them off before school.
He is more tired than usual.
I work some evenings as well
column3: but I always manage to get home before the kids bedtime.

column2: Deedee has been a huge help.
She never ceases to amaze and impress me.
It’s so important that she knows how much I truly appreciate her.
Deedee got nominated for a field trip.
She’s going to learn about S.T.E.M.
I hope she likes the program.
Deedee always looks into the future.
She has it all mapped out.
I wanted to say so much more about our week
column3: but I must apologize.

column2: I’m exhausted.
It’s going to be a very early night tonight.
I am here for another day.
My soul dances underneath the moon
column3: growing stronger from the stars.

column2: I am such a fortunate
column3: lucky woman.

column2: I may not have everything I want and need
column3: but I have everything one truly needs.

column2: I have my health
column3: I have my family
column4: I have a warm dry roof over my head
column5: and I have a full belly.

column2: Bad days come and go.
They are fleeting like a thunderstorm.
I have used the pain and agony that I have truly suffered.
I used the torment to forge myself into something strong
column3: quick

column2: I hope that I can be an example.
I hope I can be regarded as kind.
I hope my words will be heard as wise.
My soul is older than a time I can even imagine.
I do not know the full purpose of me rebirth.
Is it a gift or a punishment?
I suppose since as long as I live and breath
column3: the reason doesn’t matter.

column2: The important thing is that I am.
As a child and young adult
column3: I never slowed down enough to realize the biggest pressing matter which would inevitably consume me whole.

column2: I would be utterly powerless in its grasp.
Despite having relatives and even a good friend pass on it didn’t occur to me
column3: that I too will one day be no more.

column2: When my belly was swollen and full with unborn life getting ready to make its grand entrance
column3: it hit me hard like a stone wall.

column2: This life in me came from seemingly no where.
Sure
column3: I know the scientific process and all that... but think about one moment I am me

column2: As easily as my sweet babe can enter this world
column3: her exit could be faster.

column2: If she can go.
I can go.
Finally my mortality terrified me.
Awake in the night
column3: I tried not to cry.

column2: Crippling panic weld up inside me.
It took a few years
column3: but I’ve made my peace.

column2: I no longer worry about this absolute fact.
No matter what I do
column3: I can not stop it.

column2: So I go on.
I live my life.
I love my life.
It’s precious to me.
I take the time to value myself
column3: my family
column4: and everything that makes me smile.

column2: It’s amazing and I will take the time to enjoy it until the very end.
The last time I saw snow falling down
column3: I was running away.

column2: I made the decision to get a fresh start in life.
This choice meant picking up my kids and moving
column3: 1000 miles a way.

column2: I have yet to regret it.
I needed clarity and to remove myself from seriously
column3: negative people who caused so much drama that it seriously scarred my life.

column2: The night I left it all behind snow and hail followed me through 3 states.
I spent time by the ocean.
I healed.
A bigger picture of what and how I want my life to be was revealed.
I finally figured out how to break free of the walls of my past.
This morning I was woken up by my phone ringing way too early for me.
Annoyed
column3: I answered it.

column2: An automated message told me that school all across the district was closed today.
I got out of bed
column3: told the girls so they could sleep in
column4: and I went back to sleep.

column2: When I woke up again (at a normal hour)
column3: I peaked out the window.

column2: It was raining.
Not a single snow flake on the ground.
I’m from New England.
If this is what the South calls a “snow day” ....
it’s kind of a joke
column3: no offense.

column2: I realize that South Carolina’s DPW probably doesn’t have the resources to deal with icy roads
column3: snow accumulation

column2: However
column3: my kids were missing school on account of some cold rain.

column2: Seriously?
I had to work at 4.
As I left the house Bobo and Snoochie were trying to make a snow man out of the first few falling flakes (keep in mind
column3: by the time any of this snow actually started to stick the kids would have been home from school already).

column2: Once at work a few people called out and one guy never showed up.
We were dead for awhile
column3: but as the night wore on business picked up since we were the ONLY place open.

column2: Eventually we got the call to close early.
Patrons were seriously aggravated and annoyed with us.
By the time I left work my car was encased in a sheet of ice.
It took 15 minutes for my windows to be defrosted enough for me to be able to drive.
I made it down the street
column3: stopped for a red light
column4: and felt the breaks lock up

column2: I drove with care the rest of the ride home and it was uneventful other than passing by other cars on the road that were literally crawling at 15 mph and sliding everywhere.
Some one needs to teach these southerners how to properly BRAKE in icy conditions.
South Carolina doesn’t have any requirements regarding safety inspections for vehicles on the road.
This means that the road ways are filled with cars that really aren’t all that safe and are driving right next to you.
I imagine there’s a large amount of cars that have tires with seriously bad tread – no wonder why they freak out about driving in snow or ice – their cars aren’t safe to begin with.
shm...
I won’t lie though
column3: it’s nice to see the snow
column4: only if it’s a micro inch coating.

column2: It reminds me of all the bullshit I left behind and reinforces that I am on the right track!
ps the attempted snow man build was a total flop

column3: back in New England
column4: taken during what we thought to be one of the last snow falls we’d see in a very long while

column2: In moments of depression
column3: anxiety
column4: uncertainty I grasp on to the same M.O.

column2: I need to change something
column3: make it different

column2: I’ve gone through several dozens different hair colors
column3: piercings
column4: and of course I’ve got a few tattoos.

column2: I’ve given up most of the piercings.

I have a scar on the edge of my right ear brow from an old bar bell.
Don’t plan on ever re-piercing it again.

I got it pierced when I was 18.
I took the ring out when I got pregnant.
Don’t really care to show off my tummy anymore.

Tonight I’m sitting on a sheet in my living room with color stripper in my hair.
I’m done with my red locks.
Time for something new.
My plan is to go as blond as possible.
I’m nervous and tentative.
I know from past experience it is really difficult to dye red hair blond.
So I’m using color oops and crossing my fingers.
Oh man do I hope I don’t wind up with Ronald McDonald orange hair.
It’s happened to me once before.
When Deedee was about 2 years old I attempted to dye my hair to be as golden blond as hers.
It was a miserable
column3: epic failure.

column2: I was horrified by the shocking orange color.
I re-dyed it something darker to fix it and that was that.
I’ve never tried to dye my thick locks blond again.
The irony is
column3: I was born blond.

column2: I’ve also used supposedly temporary black dye on my hair for a special occasion.
HUGE mistake.
I had to grow the hair out that was way too dark for my complexion.
It took about 2 years.
Since my two dyeing catastrophes I’ve played it safe and stuck to reds and browns ever since.
I’m tired of looking the same way.
I live in a new state
column3: have a new job

column2: I’d like a new hair color to go along with it.
I’ve got enough tattoos and piercings anyways.
I am an awakened
column3: spirituality conscious individual.

column2: I am aware that my energy connects to every every other life force on this planet.
It is all connected.
We are all connect and tapped into the very core of the Earth.
The elements are a key source of power.
Intention is a stronger force of will than one might expect.
The key to life is simple.
Live your life.
Live it the way you want too.
I interpret that to mean enjoy each day that I have life.
Live to the fullest.
Both sentiments are not always possible.
I’d rather make the most of each day which various bumps and obstacles included.
Love yourself.
Your life is for you so give it meaningful value.
Sure
column3: you can love others too.

column2: But you can not truly love anyone else until you love yourself for all that you AND all that you are not.
Make peace with the fact that you are not perfect.
No one is
column3: so we must learn out short comings are perfectly acceptable.

column2: Embrace your flaws.
I find it a good philosophy to strive to be perfect and accept what is actuality.
In the thick of all your relationships
column3: do not have expectations.

column2: Always act with that logic in your mind.
If you work hard
column3: give selflessly in the hopes of receiving praise
column5: or anything in return you will be disappointed.

column2: Act for yourself instead.
Everything else will fall into place.
If you are in a negative mind set you should change your thinking.
The only thing you have true control over in this world is yourself.
Think and act with this in mind.
The human mind is amazing and we only use a small percentage of it.
Awaken and the possibilities will become endless.
Remember the 7 chakras.
Open them all.
Work to undo the blocks.
In a future blog I will go deeper into this.
Have a beautiful day.
Love yourself.
Love the world around you.

column3: The Man telling me today was only about me really felt nice deep inside.

column2: I know life will always have its ups and downs
column3: meetings and partings
column4: but sometimes good byes are too difficult to bear.

column2: Last night
column3: I let myself and my natural tendencies to get the better of me.

column2: The result?
I took my unfounded suspicions
column3: paranoia
column4: and anxieties out on the man.

column2: I feel terrible for this.
I’m grateful that he’s so kind hearted and understanding that he can see past this.
Maybe that’s because of the dark cloud from today.
We took one of our cats to the vet today.
The vet came highly recommended.
My sweet princess Toothless is on the decline
column3: but she’s only 4 years old.

column2: Her rear end is so tiny.
She’s lost so much weight.
Her coat is dull.
Her hind legs are so weak.
I’m watching her rot and mystified as to the cause.
I’ve been trying to eliminate the more obvious problems
column3: but as to what’s going on with her

column2: Could be her kidneys.
Could be hyperthyroidism.
Could be allergies.
Could be cancer.
Guess what?
It’s cancer.
She has a tumor in her spine.
It’s bone cancer.
It’s inoperative.
No surgery can fix this.
Chemo isn’t an option.
She’s on borrowed time.
I fought my tears as I saw the X Ray of Toothless’s disintegrating spine.
Soon she will be paralyzed and we will have to put her down.
There is no miracle coming to save the day.
Only my tears.
I was sent home with pain medication to keep her comfortable.
I was sent home with no hope.
I have my love for her still though.
I have this final time to spend with her.
She’s still my sweet girl.
She still purrs and wants to be pet.
She still places her soft
column3: velvet paws in the palm of my hand.

column2: She still nips my fingers.
I still have time with her for at least a little while.
My kids will be coming home from school soon and I’ll have to face them with the truth.
I know she’s just a cat
column3: but she’s so much more to us.

column2: She’s a member of our family.
She’s softened our moments of pain.
She’s been that needed hug.
She’s been our shoulder to cry on.
She’s that giggle of sheer joy.
Now it’s our turn to care for her like she cares for us.
I can only hope that in these final days she knows she is loved.
Jacob Mark Pitts has a gleam in his eyes.
He prowls lightly on his feet with the fluid movements of an instinctual predator.
If he was larger
column3: he wouldn’t think twice about killing you.

column2: He sleeps up high above the fridge or on top of my wired shelf.
He’s obsessed with running water (and no
column3: he is not diabetic).

column2: He runs into the bathroom and sings at full volume.
“Meeeeer-ooooW-Kkkk”.
He loves to pronounce “Ka” sounds.
He’ll tell you a story if you ask.
He’s been known to break into bathroom and join us when we take showers.
It’s just too hilarious to make a more concentrated effort to kick him out.
He does not have the ferocious appetite his brother (Andrew Dennis Beirsack) has.
Jake cares very little when I shake his bag of treats.
It’s not enough to entice him to appear.
Andy
column3: on the other hand
column4: hears the treat drawer slide open from 2 rooms away.

column2: Jake is very healthy compared to his brother.
Born into a litter of 5
column3: Jacob was the runt.

column2: He was chosen because of his slight
column3: slender frame and for the markings on his forehead.

column2: He is black
column3: but his paws are white and he has 3 patches of white fur from his neck to his belly.

column2: I made the mistake of switching his food to a different brand when the kittens were about 18 weeks old.
The store near my house doesn’t carry the brand I use.
Within 4 days of using the cheaper
column3: more common brand
column4: I watched in agony as Andy’s health sharply declined.

column2: He was lethargic
column3: he couldn’t get up to eat or drink.

column2: His breathing grew rapid and shallow.
Jake saw his brother get sicker and sicker.
Jake abandoned his dieing brother.
I used a combination of TLC
column3: science

column2: I threw out what I suspected was tainted food.
I hand fed him.
I saged him.
I gave him a white light of my energy.
Andy survived
column3: but because of his illness
column4: Jake “the runt” was bigger than his brother.

column2: Andy has fully recovered.
He’s happy and playful.
Jacob enjoys a sense of power now that he is as big as his brother.
When I get home from work Jake and Andy greet me at the door.
They make me smile.
There is something therapeutic in petting a cat.
I hate being a flake.
The list of things I want to accomplish is massive.
What I ACTUALLY manage to do is fairly meager.
For example my adhd can run rampant if I’m not actively attempting to keep it in check.
Most of the time I can... unless I’m around another high energy person.
So far at the new job I’ve managed to stay on task and focus... tonight however
column3: I got distracted.

column2: Its my own damn fault.
I’m well aware of my tendencies.
It just sucks to have to actively shut my crazy switch off so I can function like a semi-normal human.
Oh but there’s medication I can take for it!
Thanks
column3: but no thanks.

column2: I’d rather reach deep inside of me to train myself to concentrate
column3: alleviate pain

column2: I don’t like taking pills to solve a problem.
To me
column3: that is the essence of dependency.

column2: My plan was to get my emt training and pass the certification exams.
I really feel this field of work would be the best way for me to utilize my body as well as my mind.
Orginally the plan was for me to concentrate on this alone.
Did it happen?
Am I signed up for a single course?
No.
I’m not.
I do have a new job though and income.
Its not like I’ve been idle with me time.
I do need to buckle down though and speak to the admissions department so I can at least be on the right path.
In parting I’ll say this: The new year is almost here.
2016 will be dedicated towards furthering my future: body

The house shook.
It would seem as if the Ides of March have come in early this year
column3: in like a lion out like a lamb.

column3: The Man fixed the sink.

After ranting about my weight and spring time goals in my blog yesterday
column3: I fired up the yee ole wii fit.

column2: I’ve gained ten pounds since last year.
Oh crap.
It may not seem like a lot
column3: but trust me

column2: I’ve always been that awkward skinny girl who could cram anything I wanted down my throat and never gain an ounce.
I’ve actually had people seriously accuse me of being anorexic before and they’ve tried to stage an intervention.
Their false assumptions amused me.
I eat like a total pig... in fact
column3: my diet was total crap back in my skeletor days.

column2: Add that to the fact that I don’t routinely exercise and I never have.
Yes
column3: I am energetic and yes
column4: I am always in motion... but you’d never see me running miles around town.

column2: What I had was a fast metabolism.
Now that I’ve actually gained and held on to some weight
column3: I am facing the fact that my metabolism has slowed down.

column2: I’m aging.
These are the facts that I must face.
The kids had a blast watching me run on the wii
column3: do step aerobics

column2: After just two days of a 30 minute work out my thighs are aching!
I will not let this deter me and secretly I love the burning pain.

If I’m sore tomorrow I plan on sucking it up
column3: take some Aleve
column4: and stay true to my regiment.

column2: All I have to do is lose 10 pounds.
I am realistically giving myself 2 months to accomplish this.
I know I’ve got what it takes.
The Man was in a mood this morning.
I thought about it on the dark drive home from work tonight.
We’re experiencing a minor drift.
He is so important to me.
I choose him.
I love him.
I’d like to take some of his stress and frustration a way.
I need to leave in an hour to go pick him up from work.
He didn’t sleep good last night hence his grumpy cat exterior today.
My plan is to give him a nice back rub before he falls asleep.
I’m not a very outwardly affectionate person and sometimes I forget how important physical human contact can be to others.
You see
column3: as an empath who ever touches me (or vice versa) causes me to feel their emotions.

column2: It can be an overwhelming
column3: over stimulating experience.

column2: It’s not always pleasant.
You can not hide your true self from me.
When I have physical contact with other people it’s as intimate as them being naked in front of me.
With The Man it doesn’t matter.
We have nothing to hide from each other.
I had made a habit of avoiding contact so unfortunately I neglect the ones I love
column3: like The Man.

column2: He’s too bashful and grown-up to seek me out for hugs like my sweet babies do.
The wind is still roaring.
I can hear the snap of branches as a type.
I can hear debris flutter along the road.
Toothless (my kitty) is sleeping soundly in her bed next to mine.
Andy and Jake are chirping out in the hallway.
I really love my life.
A year ago I could barely stand the sight of him... or myself.
He represented all those demons stirring inside me that I desperately wanted to cast into exile.
Every day we were trapped in the same
column3: numb routine.

column2: I tried so hard to put my foot down.
I really did.
Too bad I was utterly failing myself
column3: my dreams

column2: As the snow flew in a furious white blanket
column3: blinding our eyes and freezing our exposed skin a different kind of storm raged through my mind.

column2: I love you
column3: but this is too much.

column2: You are my destruction.
I can never get better in this toxic stew.
Temperatures dropped.
Glass shattered.
So did my heart.
The moment had been forced by his hand
column3: not mine.

column2: I did what I had to do.
I did it to save my own life.
It was by far the hardest decision I’ve ever had to make.
I didn’t even get the chance to say goodbye.
There was nothing to fall back on.
I was on my own.
No more could I invoke his name in my own self destruction.
There was no one
column3: but me.

column2: It was lonely at the bottom
column3: but at least I could only rise.

column2: Surely I had sunk down as far as I could go.
Months went by and I realized just how much I missed him.
It’s funny how the sun still shines even when you’re dieing on the inside.
He’s always had my heart.
Without him it didn’t beat quite the same any more.
I couldn’t go on with the ghost of my past.
Only eagerly inch forward and with increasing momentum I grew strong.
Eventually we had to speak and we did.
It was tense those first few times.
We couldn’t even hold a conversation without ripping each other to pieces.
That’s when I realized how much I’d hurt him and it was every bit as sour as he had made me feel.
Pain the great equalizer
column3: like birth

column2: Neither of us can take back the past.
Baby steps became steady.
I heard happiness and pride in his voice.
Whether or not we would every be together again no longer mattered.
We BOTH deserve happiness.
I realized if we did want to try again
column3: it’d have to be a whole new relationship.

column2: I could never bring up anything from the past to hold against him.
More importantly I needed to forgive him.
Forgiveness
column3: giving it was a rush.

column2: A huge weight lifted off me.
I wouldn’t want every mistake I make or flaw I have recited to me over and over... so why hadn’t I held him to the same standard.
So when is too much enough... when you are no longer yourself.
When your future is at stake.
When you are being physically hurt.
When is it not enough?
When you are fortunate enough to have that rare partner who is willing to work with you every step of the way to climb from hell to heaven.
Some people are “cat” people.
Some people are “dog” people.
There are even people who aren’t big on pets altogether or maybe they are content with some colorful fish.
Different strokes for different folks.
Me
column3: I’ve always been a dog person.

column2: Its how I was brought up (not too mention my mum is terribly allergic to cats so they were never a real option).
I grew up close in age to the family dog so much so that he was more like a sibling than pet.
Losing him was like losing a brother.
Hands down he was the most loyal and intelligent animal I’ve ever had the privilege of knowing.
Dogs require a lot of money
column3: time

column2: I miss not having a dog
column3: but my situation doesn’t seem fair to thrust a dog into.

column2: In my house
column3: we have cats.

column2: Jake and Andy
column3: my idiotic kittens are a serious dose of cuteness and therapy.

column2: I love their independent streaks.
Originally I planned to take just one of them in
column3: but something about the way they are instantly made me realize I couldn’t separate them.

column2: They are best friends as well as brothers.
Andy was the mama’s boy of the liter.
He could easily be a fat cat.
He loves to fetch his toy mouse
column3: kinda like a dog.

column2: He’s fiercely protective over his food and his little brother.
The markings on his face give his expression a comical quality.
We call it derpy.
Jake was the runt.
His streamline shape and graceful movements remind me of a tiger on the hunt.
He’s vocal and loves the sound of his own voice.
Sometimes he sounds like a pigeon.
He loves to rub his head against mine.
Today was the big day.
The girls were so excited.
Ladies Day with grandma included a trip to the hair dresser (which in this household is an extremely rare indulgence).
Snoochie had been counting down the days since last week.
I have a long
column3: awkward history when it comes to going to a professional to get my hair done.

column2: It never ever comes out the way I wanted it.
On top of that
column3: they always “discover” my curls and I end up leaving feeling like a mortified poodle.

column2: I paid money to have my precious hair violated.
There’s only been one hair dresser in my life who cut
column3: styled
column4: and dyed my hair the way I liked it.

column2: That’s it.
Out of a legion of scissor holding trained stylists just the one was up to snuff.
The worst ever experience was when I was about 10 years old.
We were just about done and as I peaked in the mirror I was digging my cute pixie bob.
Suddenly the hair dresser buzzed the back of my head with clippers.
Oh no!!!
She actually gave me a duck’s ass.
I couldn’t face going to school the next day.
The front of my head looked amazing
column3: but in the back... oh my!

column2: To this day I cringe when I hear electric clippers buzzing maniacally.
When I was a teenager I stopped going to hair salons.
Long locks are pretty too after all.
When necessary I cut and dyed my own hair.
I was satisfied with the results and if I screwed up
column3: I only had myself to blame.

column2: Sometimes I’d find that rare gem of a friend who’d cut my hair for me and honestly
column3: they always did a better job than the professionals.

column2: In their younger years I cut my kid’s hair myself.
Deedee had straight blond so I’d just trim it and give her some bangs.
Snoochie is a different matter.
She has wild
column3: crazy curly hair.

column2: No matter what I did with it
column3: her hair just bounces back into a mass of wild tangles.

column2: One time I gave Snoochie bangs.
It was a huge mistake.
Lesson learned the hard way.
Nowadays I try to straighten her hair as much as possible.
As for Deedee
column3: she cuts her hair herself.

column2: She dyes it herself.
So far she’s had pretty good luck as far as her hair is concerned.
She lives for manic panic.
The girl’s special day ended later than anticipated.
A little after 10 pm the girls were dropped off.
Snoochie now rocks a soft bob and now has blond high lights!
It’s so cute.
Some one tamed Snoochie’s angry hair.
Deedee... on the other hand....
her hair has been hacked.
Her hair is way too short
column3: uneven

column2: She’s miserable.
She’s home from school today and keeps bursting into tears.
It’s obvious the poor hair dresser has little to no experience with emo hair cuts (especially choppy layers) and my sweet Deedee is paying the price.
So now I’m looking at wigs
column3: extensions
column4: or for a hair dresser with a little more experience.

column2: I hope we can compromise and find something for her.
I can’t leave her like this.
Edited to add: The Man and I took Emily to another hair salon today.
The hair dresser (Helena) made a miracle out of a terrible hair cut.
It’s super short and styled into a striking emo do and more importantly
column3: Deedee absolutely loves it.

column2: So step-grandma spends $80 on a cut and Deedee hates it.
Dad spends $15 on a hair cut and Deedee feels like a rock star!
There’s this huge news story going on right now... a two year old boy is missing.
Most likely he’s in some deep woods in Tennessee.
He slipped away from his grandma and no one has seen him since.
He disappeared a week ago.
I can’t help but get sucked up into the story like it’s a vortex.
I found myself frequently checking for updates as the days
column3: hours

column2: My attention was
column3: is drawn in deep.

column2: I read the stories and comments.
I never gave my opinion on anything even though theories play out in my mind.
My emotions tug and pull.
The horror of a lost
column3: cold
column4: small child eats at my heart.

column2: Then there was this afternoon...
3:10 pm and the school bus hadn’t rolled up yet.
By 3:15 pm I’ve got the creeps.
No intuition kicking into over drive yet
column3: but my mind started to race.

column2: 3:20 pm Snoochie’s bus should have stopped at the house by now.
I’m trying to remember what Snoochie wore to school today.
My description would be “A girl with bright blew eyes
column3: a leopard spotted jacket in blue tones

column2: 3:25 And I decide if she doesn’t come home by the time Bobo’s and Deedee’s bus drops them off I am officially beginning the frantic search.
The first 24 hours are crucial!
At 3:30 the school bus stops in front of the house.
Deedee and Bobo saunter in the house at their usual arrival time.
Snoochie was 20 minutes late.
Her bus driver forgot to stop at the house before he went to the middle school to reload the bus with more homeward bound students.
She was home though.
That’s what matters.
I can squish her with hugs.
I can kiss her cheeks til they’re red.
I can tell her “I love you” one more time.
I am the luckiest woman alive.
I have my baby.
She’s safe.
Last night was really cold
column3: below freezing.

column2: I turned the heat up so they kids would sleep comfortably.
I curled my blanket tightly around me.
I don’t see how a 2 year old in a long sleeved shirt and jeans can survive this frigid cold air.
Today it hailed and snowed for a short while.
I don’t see any chance of survival for a boy lost in the woods in this weather.
My heart aches.
I don’t know Noah Chamberlin
column3: but I’m terrified for him.

column2: Has his parents begun to give up hope?
Do they stay faithful and without doubt that they’ll see their little boy again.
I’m sorry for what they are going through.
I never want to be in their shoes.
One huge comfort I will have tonight is that my fabulous trio is safe and sound with me tonight.
I will remember how easily and quickly things can go wrong.
I will use this as a stark
column3: fresh reminder that it is always time to live in the moment and cherish life and love with all of my heart.

column2: I shall never take a hug for granted.
Update: Today they found the little boy.
Unfortunately
column3: it was too late.

column2: The past few days have been a mix of wet and cold... I didn’t think it would be possible for the lil’ guy to make it through this with some sort of miracle or divine intervention and sadly
column3: I was right.

column2: My personal opinion on the matter: He died Tuesday night.
He had no jacket
column3: no hat

column2: I think he was a fighter though.
I think he managed to survive the first couple of days
column3: but exhaustion took its toll.

column2: Yet again I will go to bed tonight thankful my babies are safe and sound under my roof.
It started from the moment Deedee could put crayon to paper.
She delighted in drawing all the splendour of her world.
After coating my fridge in her 18 month old drawings
column3: I made a startlingly revelation.

column2: Deedee always drew people and animals with a secondary outside outline.

column2: What Deedee sees so deeply is the energy that you are made of.
You emit a color scheme of light all around you
column3: whether you see it or not.

column2: Now
column3: I see it too

column2: It’s not as defined.

While you write cryptic poetry or write a short paragraph about your day... I
column3: Ianna see the depths of your very soul.

You be you and I’ll be me.

column2: Today I had a thought.
We

column2: I have a filthy potty mouth that makes truck drives blush.
I think there’s something striking about a teeny lil’ thing like me when I open up my wee lil’ mouth and the cuss words just pour out like steam.
I like to be shocking.
I won the battle of swears when I was 12.
My parents separated and my dad moved out.
My mom
column3: over powered by her 3 teenage kids just couldn’t seem to stop us from swearing.

column2: My parents never swear.
I’ve heard my mom cuss once
column3: exactly once.

column2: Dinner would go “Hey bro
column3: pass the fucking salt”.

column2: His reply “Here you go you little cunt.” To which my mom would say “You guys are awful.” We’d just laugh and laugh.
Swears lose their meaning when they become adjectives and verbs.
After a certain point of hear “you’re so cute... until you open your mouth” you learn you are growing up.
Maybe it’s time to talk like one.
There’s this list of truly forbidden swears I just can’t bear to utter.
The #1.
No no word
column3: the “N” word.

column2: So derogatory I just can’t say it.
Not ever.
GD and #3.
JC.

Retard.

Don’t mock the mentally challenged.
Not cool.
Fag.
Don’t mock gays.
Not cool.
Up North
column3: nobody says the “n” word.

column2: Nobody.
That word has fallen off the face of the planet.
Doesn’t matter if you’re white or black.
No one uses it.

column3: but it bugs me

I personally feel it’s disrespectful.
For all those people who fight racism and discrimination
column3: hearing this word all day at work it’s a slap in the face.

column2: That’s right.
I’m half white
column3: half Hispanic and the “n” word really bothers me.

Monkey see
column3: monkey do.

column2: So wouldn’t constant use of the “n” word keep it in circulation even with non blacks who have “no right” to say it?

Although I have a great number of opinions on the hot topics sweeping across the country
column3: I usually keep my personal thoughts to myself.

column2: When online or dealing with other people
column3: I try to follow this method:

column2: T – is it true?
H – is it helpful?
I  – is it inspiring?
N – is it necessary?
K – is it kind?
When reviewing my mental check list if it appears not to follow within these guidelines

As I mentioned in a previous post
column3: I’ve been closely following the case of 2 year old Noah Chamberlin who ran away from his grandmother and sister during a nature walk on a warm January afternoon.

column2: After an exhausting week long search
column3: Noah was found

column2: There were many cold
column3: wet nights and it’s very conceivable the poor child expired from exposure and hypothermia.

column2: What made this news story particularly fascinating to me was the overwhelming amount of volunteers
column3: search dogs
column4: and technology used in a desperate attempt to find the boy.

column2: All methods failed.
However
column3: the area police refused to acknowledge that maybe there was more that meets the eye and that this could possible be anything more than an “accident”.

column2: The police claim Noah’s family would never harm him and that they were a good
column3: Christian family.

column2: I went into my critical thinking mode... the statements made about this family irked me in so many ways.
Seriously?
Are Christians found to be impossible of committing crimes?
Inflicting child abuse?
Committing murder?
Is Christianity a defense used to prove some one innocent?
What if Noah was a black child?
Would the police still be persisting the family’s uninvolvement of the child’s disappearance?
Would the search still have been massive?
I honestly don’t think it would have been the same if Noah wasn’t white.
I’m sorry to state this and raise this point
column3: but I truly feel the police would have been pointing fingers if Noah came from a black family

column2: I think race and religion has EVERYTHING to do with it.
White parents have harmed their children.
Christian parents have harmed their child.
Examples of child abuse
column3: murder
column4: and the like have been found in EVERY ethnic group

column2: No one categorized group is exempt.
Please realize
column3: I’m not saying this family is guilty of lying to police to cover anything up.

column2: I don’t know them.
I haven’t met them.
I was never a part of this nor am I an expert on the matter.
In fact
column3: if anything I feel sorrow and pity for the family.

column2: If this tragedy happened accidentally as stated
column3: than I can only imagine the pain and heaviness in their hearts.

column2: I hope that one day the wounds won’t sting so much.
I hope the agony doesn’t tear an innocent family apart.
Who am I to question their story?
I’m no one really.
I am simply an individual who doesn’t approve of some one using religion to proclaim innocence.
Maybe it’s because I am not a Christian that this bothers me so much and rubs me the wrong way.
I just don’t see how skin color
column3: religion
column4: and like makes one exempt from committing crimes against humanity or disregarding the welfare of another being.

column2: Inanna
“Inanna is the Queen of Heaven and Earth”
Inanna is a Mesopotamian / Sumerian deity
column3: a goddess.

column2: She is one of the first Earthly Anunnaki offspring.
Some associate her with Istar or Isis
column3: but neither of those figure heads are the reincarnation of Inanna.

column2: Inanna is not a daughter of Adam.
She was a very passionate woman
column3: although she always retained a youthful appearance.

column2: She had a very complex
column3: dynamic personality that ranged from sensuous lover to fierce warrior.

column2: In ancient portrayals of her
column3: she is pulled by lions on a chariot.

column2: While many of the ancient deities earned the title “Mother Goddess”
column3: Inanna did not although she was referred to as “Morning Star”.

column2: She is also closely associated with resurrection and reincarnation for she was able to travel to the Underworld and than back to Earth.
It’s a fascinating
column3: ancient myth.

column2: In fact
column3: mentions of Inanna go as far back to some of the first ever recorded word.

column2: Inanna was powerful as well as lustful.
She conquered knowledge
column3: reincarnation

column2: She was a lover as well as a warrior and renowned for both qualities equally.
In the United States it is Thanksgiving today.
Even though I’m American this just isn’t one of my favorite holidays.
I hate squash and I’m not big on turkey either.
While I do appreciate the sentiment of taking a day or a moment to reflect upon what I am thankful for before a long cold winter sets in
column3: I feel one should gratefully list these assets at the end of each and everyday for each day that we live is truly a gift.

column2: The concept behind the first Thanksgiving is so removed from this modern age.
To me
column3: celebrating it in a way that customs dictate seems to be hypocritical and condescending.

column2: It would be one thing if the early Americans didn’t abuse and kill the Native Americans or if their culture and beliefs hadn’t been obliterated
column3: but that is the true history between these cultures.

column2: So celebrating Thanksgiving and ignoring the history seems like an ignorant joke to me.
I know people mean well
column3: but maybe we should pick a different day for this type of celebration.

column2: In this day and age Thanksgiving symbolizes the start of the count down to Christmas.
Its all to commercialized for my taste.
Having been brought up Roman Catholic I celebrate Christmas because it is expected and my kids enjoy participating in all the holiday events.
I feel like a traitor turning my back on my personal beliefs just to go with flow.
I think this is the year I will turn my back on Christmas and celebrate an older holiday instead.
C’mon Yule!
I miss the fellowship... it’s hard to explain and if you’re actually reading this I apologize.
It’s probably not something you’d be able to understand.
It’s just me giving into what most of society would assume to be a delusion.
I can try to explain the madness and the insanity
column3: but at the end you’d just doubt me and that is something my heart can not take right now.

column2: The easiest thing for me to be honest about is this – I’m an empath.
That means that I experience the feelings of others through a connective process (speech
column3: touch

column2: I feel their feelings as if they are my own.
I can not distinguish what is actually me or some one else.
Others near me might see me burst into tears or giggle which can occur at highly inappropriate times.
It happens when some one connected with me experiences a very powerful emotion.
On the day of the Paris terror attacks I was very unsettled.
I keep telling the man no one has the right to end someone else’s life.
I didn’t know what kept making me say that.
It didn’t pertain to anything going on in my life and yet I was scared
column3: sad

column2: I found out that night about the attacks and when I calculated the time zone difference it was exactly when I had my “anxiety” attack.
My mood can effect the mood of others with no verbal or physical output.
My emotions leak into the air.
If I had a bad day at work everyone experiences my tension when I walk in my front door even if I don’t reflect my mood.
For the good and well being of those I love
column3: it’s imperative that I always stay positive.

column2: Sometimes people “hear” my thoughts.
They know the exact phrase I’ll think in my head even if I said nothing in reality.
I really despise this phenomenon.
My thoughts should be just for me especially if I never intended to vocally utter them.
I could go on and on about my peculiar quirks.
I use to belong to an online community connecting me to people like me.
There ended up being too much drama so I dropped it like a bad habit.
Days like today make me wish that I hadn’t.
I miss feeling like a drop in the oddball ocean.
In my isolation I feel like I stick out like a sore thumb.
I’m forced to keep this part of me hidden for fear of violent scrutiny.
I’m counting down the days.
Counting out of excitement.
Counting out of misery.
It’s disconcerting to be counting both for good and for bad.

column2: One would be wise to take caution when dealing with such a person.
Your energy field is their food.

column3: not when it counts.

Precognition isn’t something that I can call on at will

column2: I can communicate with others like me from a distance within my mind.

I can NOT talk to ghosts / spirits and RARELY do I see them.

There is no place for me in the bible.
By my very nature (creative
column3: independent
column5: I follow a left hand path.

column2: God has no place for me.
I do not dwell on it.
My soul is immortal.
I have lived
column3: died
column4: and been reborn many many times.

column2: I am a flawed
column3: simple human – the same as you.

column2: It’s getting late (for me anyways).
For once I’m sort of stumped on what to write.
Usually I can always think of some thing.
I feel an idea for a topic beginning to shake up in my mind.
I’m dyslexic.
If you’ve read my journal before you might have noticed a few grammatical errors.
Yeah
column3: I’m the chick who can’t always type a coherent sentence
column4: but in my head I do!

column2: I also have a strong bad habit of leaving words out or substituting the wrong word for a word I had really meant to say.
If I focus really hard I can correct myself
column3: but more often than not my brain just sees what it wants to see and I won’t notice my grammar breech at all.

column2: I have a high iq despite my set back.
My level of “disability” is mainly effected when it comes to output I give (writing and speech) and not at all with input.
I can speed read.
I’ll read from the top of a page to the bottom with a quick diagonal nod of my head.
It’s extremely important to me to stay as sharp as possible.
I love to write.
I have notebooks upon notebooks with free flow poems and short stories I’ve never successfully managed to finish.
Reading is a way of life for me.
Reading inspires me.
Library trips in my household occur weekly.
We don’t have cable.
I’m proud to say that all 3 of my babies are book worms
column3: especially Bobo.

column2: The Man is the most avid
column3: dedicated reader.

column2: He’s always in the middle of a book.
I mix up numbers.
It’s easier for me to read a group of numbers and recite them than it does for me to repeat back a random grouping in sequential order.
I need a surgeons level of care and attention when I’m making a financial transaction.
In my head I know it
column3: but something goes haywire when I need it to apply.

column2: Don’t ask me for directions.
I have trouble with the concept of left and right.
It disorients me for some reason I can’t fathom.
The big irony is that I understand north
column3: west

column2: I am no stranger to a map.
I never get lost
column3: ever

column2: I have a very accurate internal compass.
In my head east
column3: south
column5: and west are 2 D while left and right are 3 D and make my head spin.

column3: I’d try not to look at you.

column2: I’d just keep going about my business and give you that glare of mine that makes you feel like I’m looking right through you.

column3: is ideal

column2: Sorry for thinking the world of you.

I grew up in an old
column3: big

column2: It had been my home since the minute my parents brought me home from the hospital.
The horse hair plastered walls and wooden beams hold the precious memories of my infancy.
My mother would sit in her rocking chair and nurse me.
I’m getting to old to comprehend just how those earlier years went.
I imagine baths in the kitchen sink
column3: sleeping soundly in the nursery
column4: my mom pacing around trying to sooth a swaddled infant me.

column2: I grew up knowing there was more to the house than what meets the eye.
I always sensed that not only was something not quite right
column3: but even when I was alone

column2: Certain spots in the house chilled me to the bone.
One spot that particularly scared me was the landing on the stair well between the 1st and 2nd floor.
I never walked up and down those stairs.
I always ran up them
column3: jumped down them

column2: Those stairs stirred a feeling of sheer terror in me.
They felt sinister.
Everyone has got a ghost story about my old house.
I have a whole life time’s worth that I could easily write a novel dedicated to the paranormal activity that occurred within those walls.
Some stories scared the daylight out of me.
Some make me go “hmmm”
column3: but one story in particular simply brings a smile to my face.

column2: My sister use to tell me that a ghost lived in her bedroom.
“It’s an old lady
column3: ” she’d tell me.

column2: “She sits in mom’s old rocking chair by the window.
She’s a nice old lady ghost.
She protects me from the bad ghosts.” I believed my sister.
I never
column3: ever
column4: not once SAW the old lady
column5: but I could certainly feel her.

column2: Her essence was sad
column3: but protective.

column2: Sometimes I had friends over.
After they’d return from using the second floor bath (which was 2 rooms a way from my sister’s bedroom) they’d remark to me: “I didn’t know your grandmother lives with you.” Wait... what?
Neither of my grandmothers lived with us.
In fact they rarely even visited that house.
Over the years people who visited my old
column3: red house FREQUENTLY reported seeing an elderly lady sitting in the rocking chair in my sister’s bedroom.

column2: They innocently assumed that this was a real person and probably a relative of mine.
My friends were mystified when I’d lead them right back up stairs and prove that there was in fact
column3: no one in that room.

column2: Eventually my mom sold the house.
I grew up.
I started a family of my own.
I still thought of the spirits that inhibited my old house from time to time
column3: but only the ones that really scared me.

column2: One day I was having a talk with my daughter.
She’s very driven to the paranormal.
I was trying to encourage her not to mess with dangerous spirits.
Our conversation led us to talking about guardian angels.
“Did you know that I can see your guardian angel?” She confided in me.
Curious
column3: I pressed her to give me a description of my “angel”.

column2: What my daughter said shocked me.
“She’s old.
She has very grey hair and it’s pulled back into a bun
column3: but she has fly-a-ways on top of her forehead.

column2: She wears a ruffled
column3: ivory

column2: The outfit is complete with a pair of sturdy
column3: black
column5: heeled boots.” As my daughter described this so called angel the hair on my arms began to stand up.

column2: I’ve heard this description before ... many years ago when I was a teenager.
“She sits in a rocking chair near a window in a room with blue flowered wallpaper.” Okay
column3: now I’m thoroughly creeped out.

column2: My daughter was describing my sister’s old bedroom to me.
It was a room my daughter has never seen with her own eyes or even in a picture.
“The old lady is sad
column3: but she loves you.” Explained my daughter.

column2: “She’s watched over you since you were born and she tries to keep you safe.” Isn’t that what a guardian angel does?
I thought about me
column3: as an infant and a sweet old lady ghost seeing me

column2: I thought about her maternal instincts and what it might have meant for her to be dead
column3: and yet care for a living child.

column2: Senses of love and responsibility never left her
column3: not even in death.

column2: So
column3: here I am
column4: the infant all grown up and I feel proud to say that I have a ghost who watches over me.

column2: I got a new book from the library today and it’s written by an author I don’t know.
Usually when I pick a book to cuddle up with I stick to authors I know and enjoy.
Jim Butcher
column3: James Patterson

column2: Andrews
column3: Stephen King have all written books that I immensely enjoyed.

column2: The book I’m about to start is “When We Were God’s” a novel of Cleopatra by Colin Falcorner.
I’m a big history buff especially when it comes to ancient Egypt
column3: Sumeria

column2: I love how the rulers became gods and goddesses forever engrained with time and sand.
I’m not sure if this book will be an accurate depiction of the authentic life of Cleopatra
column3: but I have a healthy imagination to be entertained regardless.

column2: What I’d really love to find is books about the Anunnaki gods and specifically
column3: Inanna.

column2: My soul pulls so strongly to her.
It’s beyond fascination.
It’s obsession.
I love how her traits resemble me.
I love her lust for war or love.
My local library doesn’t carry any pagan books never mind the anything referencing the ancient anunnaki dynasty.
It’s a shame.
I’ll need to use amazon and google if I want that type of literature.
I suppose I’ll make do reading about Cleopatra.
A good story can inspire dreams larger than the stars.
I’ve got the winter blues.
Life lately has been limited to work
column3: running errands
column4: watching a lil’ bit of tv

column2: My high points have been going out to eat with The Man at our favourite restaurant (well
column3: my favourite restaurant) and the new kitty scape we purchased for the boys.

column2: That’s been it.
Kind of lame and not exactly living it up if you ask me.
I’ve got Saturday off and The Man usually has Saturdays off.
The weather has been fairly mild lately.
I didn’t even need a jacket today.
The gears in my head are moving
column3: forming a plan...

column2: Last Summer we took the chillens on an Epic Hike Day.
We hiked 2 mountains and made it 1/2 way up a third when Deedee decided she’d had enough.
We never made it to the top of Table Rock Mountain.
I heard the view is breath taking.
I for one
column3: was in love with the trail we were on.

column2: The picture in this blog is from Blue Moutain Ridge and in the distance is Table Rock.
All fall and this winter The Man and I keep talking about going back and finishing what we started.
Picnic lunch on the top of a Mountain
column3: taking in the view – sounds like my ideal date!

column2: I plan on bringing the idea up tomorrow when I see The Man.
He’s been feeling sick lately and can’t seem to shake off some sort of bug.
He may not be up for it.
I’m crossing my fingers.
I need a day spent with my feet on the Earth
column3: surrounded by trees and sky.

column2: I need the exercise.
I need this moment!
It’s just the thing to cure my winter blues.
This week is all highs.
I’m up above the clouds in disbelief that my life has taken such a huge turn for the better.
I use to think suicide was beginning to look like an attractive option.
Now I’m glad I that I refused to give up.
I didn’t feel like I had anything to live for
column3: but I didn’t want my kids growing up thinking that I didn’t love and care about them enough to try living for just a bit more.

column2: I’ve been working out almost every day.
I’ve taken a shine to Zumba (at home
column3: on my wii).

column2: I hate working out in public.
I’m very stiff and rigid.
I don’t have fluid nor graceful movements.
I rarely gesture.
So while I love dancing and moving my body in motions that feel foreign I am rather self conscious about it.
In private settings I could care less.
I did a few routines last night.
The Man joined me.
It seemed like more of a game to us than a work out.
Afterwards he sat and talked with me a bit.
Long story short he’s concerned about his health and his weight.
He’s worried about diabetes.
It’s in his family.
It’s not a fate he wants.
Luckily he can do something about it.
So the good news is I have an exercise buddy.
We’re in this together.
With our work schedules being crazy and opposing lately we’ve had trouble sharing the family jeep.
I spend about an extra 2 hours of my day driving to and from The Man’s job so that I can get to mine.
Today
column3: we solved the problem.

column2: I am now the proud owner of a Ford Mustang.
It’s not the newest nor the best model there is
column3: but the price was definitely right.

column2: I’m not sure which one of us likes it more.
The best part is: it’s a standard!!!
I love driving stick.
If I ended my life a few bad years ago I would miss being the proud owner of a mustang.
I’d miss getting the chance to make things right with the man.
I’d miss the kittens who I’d never own and yet give me so much love.
I’d miss watching my kids grow.
Time is given.
You can’t buy it.
You can give it up
column3: but then you’re the one missing out.

column2: Dreams are supposed to be the windows to our subconscious.
If you pay attention dreams can reveal our inner fears
column3: hearts desires
column4: and even details of our lives we failed to see with our eyes open.

column2: Dreams can mean so many things.
All too often some one tells me about their dreams
column3: their nightmares.

column2: Some dreams are scary
column3: others profound
column4: and some make no sense what so ever.

column2: Regardless
column3: I can’t help but feel left out.

column2: I’ve been told that everyone who sleeps dreams.
That isn’t a very useful fact.
Whether I dream or not I almost ALWAYS can not remember them.
After I slip away from awareness
column3: it just goes black.

column2: One second I am awake
column3: then asleep
column4: next thing I know I am groggy

column2: I am 33 and I can recall only about 20 dreams or so and those were very prophetic and symbolic.
When I meditate
column3: sometimes I have a lucid dream
column4: but that’s a very different thing.

column2: A strange thing does happen though... sometimes while I’m groggy I willl get a vibe about some one I know or even a place.
An example would be that sometimes while still groggy I’ll think of a co worker and an emotion attached to them.
Then when I see that person they will tell me they dreamed of me and the tone and type of the dream will be whatever emotion I felt.
Its unnerving
column3: but by this point I am use to it and I control it.

column2: The rabbit hole gets deeper.
I am in full control of these dream visits.
If I focus on a person or a place
column3: that person will tell me I visited them in a dream that felt extremely real.

column2: If I visit a location after I’ve dreamt it I can tell you weird details (like what’s hidden in a dresser drawer if I checked it out in a dream) and I can physically validate these details once a wake.
Its weird
column3: I know...

column2: So I may not dream in a typical sense
column3: but my brain is definitely up to something while I sleep.

column2: From high above the water crashes down
Dampened skin
column3: hearts pounding heavy

column2: In the dark cave
column3: behind the water fall

column2: Your arms wrapped my frame
It’s time say good bye
This is the only way
One soul has been claimed
And I choose it to be you
The moment is at hand
In the dark Ba swings his sword
You never saw it coming
I kiss at gash as the blood runs down
You were my ultimate sacrifice
I stare into your eyes
In that moment as you take your last breath
You have a revelation as the light shines bright
column3: calling you home

column2: Love and Hate is the same
In the eyes of Inanna
For centuries I have paid the price for your death
Always missing you
column3: always longing

column2: Never able to trust again
I hear your call in the wind
I taste your kisses in the rain
I can’t find you my love
I’m paying the price
In this immortality
column3: I am reborn

column2: Only to be haunted by the ghost of you
