column2: Last night J’s cousin messaged him to comment on how Deedee seems like such a “dark” kid and how her FB page is filled with posts about emo / goth bands and creepy pasta stuff.
“What the heck happened to her?!?
Rash judgement of Deedee drives me up a wall.
Yes
column3: she likes to wear dark colors.

column2: Yes
column3: she listens to emo music.

column2: Yes
column3: she’s a horror movie buff.

column2: What happened?
Nothing.
She’s 14.
If said cousin had paid any attention to Deedee while we lived closer he might have noticed she has Asperger’s Syndrome.
She separates herself from her peers.
When she takes up a hobby
column3: she’s obsessive about it.

column2: She has ALWAYS been this way.
When she was 10
column3: I took her and my other 2 babies to Disney World.

column2: Deedee tried to pack all of her stuff by herself.
When I double checked her suitcase
column3: I discovered that every article of clothing she packed was BLACK!

column2: I’ve tried to get her to wear a more colorful wardrobe and she clearly doesn’t want to.
She’s 14.
It’s a phase.
When she stopped listening to Katie Perry and Selena Gomez and pronounced her love for “My Chemical Romance”
column3: I listened to her new favorite bands.

column2: My opinion: The lyrics are inspiring.
I can see how an isolated teenager can relate to it.
There’s really nothing demonic about it.
Her favorite movies are “The Nightmare Before Christmas”
column3: “Coraline”

column2: Not to mention she likes an assortment of seemingly strange Japanese anime movies.
Her favorite store at the mall is “Hot Topic”.
*sigh*
At her school the other kids listen to rap.
They like Wayne and Drake.
They listen to songs that talk about getting drunk
column3: gang violence

column2: This type of music
column3: to me

column2: Some of her classmates drink
column3: smoke

column2: Most of them aren’t virgins.
Deedee comes from a generation that is growing up too fast for ones so young.
Deedee doesn’t drink.
She doesn’t smoke.
The closet thing to sex she’s experienced is that she kissed a boy ONCE.
She chooses her friends wisely.
Honestly
column3: if said cousin thinks she’s “too emo” than what would he prefer?

column2: She’s too old for barbies and my little pony.
Would he feel better if she was posting selfies while scantily dressed
column3: trying to attract the wrong kind of attention?

column2: Would he prefer a regressed 14 year old posting pictures of kittens and unicorns?
For crying out loud
column3: she’s growing up.

column2: She’s rearranging her looks
column3: she’s discovering her identity.

column2: I also feel the need to mention who is said cousin to judge her?
He’s not a dad.
Supposedly he has a kid
column3: who he has never met nor supported for a single second in the child’s life.

column2: Said cousin is a bar scene alcoholic who picks up the “easiest” or drunkest girls and takes them home for a one nighter.
He’s never been a role model to any child in his extended family.
He should worry about himself instead of a 14 year old autism spectrum girl who is very passionate about her hobbies.
If you ask me
column3: Deedee is a rare gem.

column2: She reads H.P.
Lovecraft and manga.
She likes going to the library.
She’s insistent that she needs to be in ALL honors classes next year when she goes to high school.
She’s adamant about going to college.
I never have to tell her to do her homework.
I rarely ever have to correct her.
She listens to her teachers
column3: her dad

column2: She’s never had a detention.
She’s such a GREAT kid it’s to the point where she’s earned the right to wear what she wants (band tee shirts and black skinny jeans).
She’s earned the right to listen to what she wants.
I can’t force her to be some one she’s not just because she’s a “dark” kid.
And if she appears a little dark and stormy
column3: so what?

column2: She’s been betrayed by adults that she trusted.
Said cousin use to encourage her dad to drink and be more involved in his metal band than his kids (not that case anymore – her father’s 1st priority is his offspring).
Funny how he doesn’t see how his own hand set this course for her.
Deedee hadn’t had the most stable
column3: supportive
column4: peachy upbringing despite how deeply loved she is.

column2: My point is
column3: she’s amazing.

column2: If said cousin actually bothered to TALK to her before he judged her by her FB shares
column3: maybe he’d realize that her darkness is an excuse to push her peers away due to her crippling social anxiety and that underneath the music and clothes

column2: I proudly live in a household void of cable tv.
We do watch movies
column3: have video game systems
column4: and have some technology available at our finger tips.

column2: I like to binge watch various tv series when I feel the longing to be lazy.
My last great thriller was Vikings.
Currently I’ve taken a shine to American Horror Story – Freak Show.
Admittedly
column3: it isn’t for everyone.

column2: I have a gravitational pull towards the macabre so it right up my alley.
I’ve watched most of the other seasons.
I’ve seen all of Murder House
column3: most of Asylum

column2: Thoroughly engrossed in Freak Show
column3: making connections to the past seasons

column2: Our history
column3: as humans (not limited any one country) has dark secrets tucked away.

column2: We use to incarcerate people who suffered from mental health issues
column3: mental retardation
column5: or even people who had the unfortunate luck to be poverty stricken.

column2: Was it right?
Morally
column3: on an individual basis absolutely not.

column2: Did it help society?
Shockingly the answer might be maybe.
I started to make all sorts of connections.
It’s a daily habit for me to read the news daily.
My heart shatters while I read stories of violent crimes
column3: rising drug use

column2: It seems like once a day I come across an article where some one committed a murder suicide and selfishly ended some one else’s life in addition to their own.
Are we expressing this hideous behavior on a larger scale than back in the days of out casting and institutionalizing?
It’s that where most of this stems from?
Are we experiencing a huge deficit of treating mental health?
We can’t go back to the old system even if my theory is correct.
To dump our special needs and disabled neighbors and family members off like a bag of trash is cruel as it gets.
Nobody deserves that fate
column3: especially those who are innocent.

column2: I don’t have the answers on how to help society’s growing number of sociopaths and deviants
column3: but throwing out the whole bushel of perfectly good apples just because there was one rotten one comes at too high of a cause.

column2: I don’t even think these people were locked away for the purpose of protecting the greater good or to get the help and care that they needed.
Sadly I think they were subjected to imprisonment so we would be more of a cookie cutter society.
We could go on with our lives
column3: pretending they didnt exist.

column2: It’s a sad part of our history.
I’ve read so many other people’s journals and I can literally feel their sorrow
column3: anxiety

column2: It’s a weird experience.
Then again
column3: I’m weird.

column2: This week at work has been hectic.
I make it through my shifts with ease though.
Ever since I experienced my latest awakening
column3: I’ve been more in tune with the others around me.

column2: I don’t take slights personally.
I accept and appropriate constructive criticism and try to gain from it.
I’m even able to give my co-workers a glimpse at big boss they never noticed.
He isn’t bad
column3: I told them.

column2: He’s stressed and pressured.
He goes about things in an “angry panicked” manner
column3: but he means well.

column2: A thought I’ve been having lately is related to telepathy.
I wonder how many people experience this and do not realize that they indeed are picking up on some one else’s emotions and thoughts – all without words.
In a sense if more people had this extra sense
column3: humanity would eventually begin to a resemble a collective hive colony like ants or bees.

column2: What would that do in regards to violent world conflicts?
Religious genocide?
Territorial disputes?
I’m sure not every problem would simply evaporate if humans could think as one collective unit
column3: but I think globally we would have more harmony in our lives.

column2: We would care more for each other.
We would work as the ultimate team.
We’d have the same goals.
With those thoughts in mind
column3: if we did indeed share a collective conscious would we be superior to those who do not (as in most people alive today)?

column2: What would be some of the downfalls?
Surely loss of individually would be at stake
column3: but to me the pro’s outweigh the cons.

column2: I’ve heard “reports” (and I mean report loosely) that alien civilizations communicate through telepathy and their society uses a collective conscious.
Is that why they “seem” more advanced than us?
So those are my thoughts tonight.
My phone (and internet) will be off from 12 am today straight through Monday.
I could refill
column3: but I rather stick to my budget schedule.

column2: I haven’t checked the cycle
column3: but tonight it sure seems like it’s a full moon.

column2: Guests were at their worst.
Screaming
column3: swearing
column4: making a fuss – they didn’t treat us like we’re humans too and we matter.

column2: There is nothing wrong with standing up
column3: being strong

column2: However
column3: just remember to treat every one as an equal.

column2: NO ONE is more important than anyone else.
We all matter.
Every life that lives and breaths matters.
Good night

I don’t care.

column3: right now that we have enough fur babies in this house.

column2: Okay here goes.
I proclaim that this sweet guy is the LAST kitten I’m adopting... for now.
If tragedy strikes one or the kids move out with their cats only then may I get another.
I can not wait.
Little Ben is only two weeks old and just opened his eyes.
It’ll be another 4 – 6 weeks before I can bring him home.
I have a thing about making sure my pets were given adequate time with their mother.
Wean them too soon and you may get a fur baby with a less than desirable disposition.
Since I have kids it’s important that we do all we can to ensure a happy
column3: confident kitty.

column2: This morning the concept of getting another cat was the furthest thing from my mind... than I went to work.
My sweet co-worker and I were talking about cats and she mentioned how her cat just had kittens.
I saw a picture and well I’m sucker for teensy paws.
There was one and only one obstacle that stood in the way.
My loving partner would surely try to bring me softly back to reality.
So I waged war.
I sent him a picture of Ben and asked “Can I have him?”.
The response was music to my ears.
“I just can’t say no to you”.
As much as The Man probably meant that
column3: what I think he really meant was “I can’t say no to teeny lil’ paws.”

column2: I am always where I am supposed to be.
That may not be where I think I should be.
It also may not be where you think I should be.
Despite all odds
column3: my location is always perfect.

column2: Do you know why that is?
I do.
It’s destiny.
Not all souls who wander are lost.
The Gaelic saying applies to me.
My soul is that of an eager adventurer always in search of something new to see.
My eyes take in the sights as if I were a plant soaking in the dew.
I prefer forest to beach
column3: beach to city
column4: but any place is as good as any to wander.

column2: I drive by ransacked
column3: abandoned dwellings and I wonder “what’s the story”?

column2: I can feel the presence of the past.
Every place has its own mood.
I love the smell of sun beams through windows.
I love the smell of water running over smoothed rocks.
My senses are easily contented.
When I was 14 or so my mother and I drove from Massachusetts to New Jersey.
On the returning trip home
column3: the map flew out the window (this was the age before GPS and cell phones).

column2: My mother panicked.
To her being lost is like a death sentence.
It’s a source of anxiety.
To me
column3: it’s simply a matter of refocusing on which way to go.

column2: The Earth is only so big after all.
What’s the matter with getting a little side tracked.
I don’t remember how I did it exactly
column3: but I picked highways that felt right.

column2: I hadn’t traveled that route ever before
column3: but using my stellar internal compass I navigated us home.

column2: My mother was grateful and stunned.
So where ever I may go
column3: I am never really lost because at that exact moment I’m exactly where I need to be.
